bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, September 29, 1952

div1.p: Hench expresses concern about the planned repairs to Building No. 1. He is worried that little of the original building will remain if the repairs are too extensive. Hench had envisioned that the Americans and Cubans could raise enough money to enclose Building No. 1 in a larger structure in order to protect it from the elements. Hench urges Nogueira to save as much of the discarded lumber as possible because souvenirs could be made of the remnants.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Pedro Nogueira, September 29, 1952
div1.opener:
September 29, 1952
Dr. Pedro Nogueira
Marti 219, Marianao
Habana, Cuba
My dear Pedro:
div1.p:
I have read with great interest your letter of September 23 regarding
the delayed dedication of Camp Lazear and the repairing of Building
No. 1. I hope you received my wire.

I am somewhat concerned about the repairs. If you plan to repair it so
that it will withstand the elements, including hurricanes, will you not
have to do such an extensive job of repairing that little of the original
will remain? In that case, we would end up with hardly anything but a
replica of the original building. My own hope embodied in the original
plan was that when the Cuban Government had gone so far as to preserve
the camp site, the Americans and perhaps Cubans could raise enough money
to enclose Building No. 1 in a suitable covering building, in which case
Building No. 1 would only have to be repaired enough to keep it standing.
In that way almost all of the original wood could be spared.

However in view of the plans which you and your colleagues deem necessary,
may I ask you, Pedro, most earnestly to save as much as possible of the
discarded original wood. I myself am very anxious to get some of it to
use for souvenirs such as pen holders, picture frames, desk ornaments,
etc. There are many physicians and certain institutions in this country
who would be delighted to have a souvenir made from the original wood of
Building No. 1. I will feel greatly relieved if you will instruct the
repairmen to save carefully all of this wood. I hope indeed there won't
be too much of it and that the repairs won't be so extensive that much of
the original wood will be discarded. Later we can arrange to have you
send me a suitable amount of this wood; probably you may want to keep
some yourself. Or, if by chance I can get to the dedication, I could
bring some back with me in a package.

Pedro, here is another thought. If there are certain areas that have to
be removed extensively, which would be better - to remove the original
wood and replace it with new wood or to leave the old wood as an inner
frame and have a new, strong outer shell put on, preserving just as much
of the original wood as possible, such as the tonged-and-grooved walls.
In that case, although the outer part might be changed somewhat, when one
walks into the building one would get the real impression of the building
as it originally was.

I still will not be completely happy until you and I are able to engage
in a cooperative effort to raise funds to erect a permanent protecting
memorial about the little building, having the latter in a museum room
which would be merely an annex to another building, useful for public
purposes, such as a public health unit or some other type of useful
memorial.

I certainly wish that I could come for the dedication on December 3. My
time is so limited that I hesitate greatly to ask the Clinic for the time.
Also my expenses have been so heavy this year that I have to think about
that too. Nevertheless the temptation to fly to Havana and back in order
to be there on December 3 is very great. Therefore I hope you will keep
me in touch with the situation.

It would have been nice to have the dedication on November 20 since that
was the day the camp was inaugurated but I can understand the interest of
your colleagues in having it on December 3.

Regarding the Sternberg book, it was mailed to you on August 14 and was
sent registered mail, with a return receipt requested. The delay may be
due to the fact that it was sent regular mail instead of air mail. These
books are not easy to find. One turns up in a catalog only every three
or four years and I hope indeed this one has not been lost.
I shall await further news from you with great interest.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
P.S.: Now that the date for the dedication of the camp has been changed,
perhaps the Surgeon General could come and therefore I would suggest that
you invite him as well as General Streit, (Head of Walter Reed Hospital).
